title: How to write a letter to the headmaster of the school for making a cycle shed - Quora

response.answer_text: Rita, the letter that you are writing is a proposal letter. Of course, sending it to the headmaster, you want a polished and professional letter. Your aim in this letter is to gain the headmaster’s support. In the business world you are currying buy-in from a principal. When you plan your proposal, you should first sit down and define the following: Who is your audience.You should consider whether or not your audience has any existing knowledge of the subject of your proposal.Does your headmaster already know of a need for a bike shed?Also, define the main point that you want to drive home with this proposal.If you can only get one point across to your headmaster, what is it?Now you must concisely define your issue.What situation does it apply to?What are the reasons behind the issue?Make sure that you identify any underlying reasons that are not so obvious.Who does this plan benefit?Has anyone tried it before?If so, was it successful?Define your solution.The proposal must define the problem and offer a solution.Consider that you may have to “win over” the headmaster’s opinion.If you see the solution as a logical solution, then use the logic in defining the solution.Try to think of your solution in terms of objectives— what is the goal that your solution must achieve?You must define a budget for your solution. (You can shop for sheds online, or go down to a local hardware store and ask for some help.)Before you write up the proposal, make an outline with all of this information.Be sure to consider the style of your proposal. Is this a persuasive argument?You can use an emotional appeal, there is nothing wrong with that, but you must found your argument on the facts.Now you can actually write your proposal. Start with an introduction paragraph, and be sure to use a hook to pull your reader into the proposal. Use background information, and then hit your audience with the proposal. After the introduction you will start the body of the proposal off by stating the problem. What is the problem? What is causing the problem? What are the effects of the problem? Next propose your solution. Show how the solution will directly solve the problem, how it speaks to the root cause, and how it will alleviate the effects. Show how your proposed budget will provide the solution. Cite your sources for your budget. Finally conclude the proposal by mirroring the introduction. If there are consequences for not accepting this proposal, point them out in your conclusion. Don’t forget to thank your audience for considering your proposal. Good luck on getting the school to build your bike shed.
